Problem:
Consider a scenario where a function z(t) measures the temperature at a point in space, evolving according to the heat equation \\(\\frac{\\partial z}{\\partial t} = \\alpha \\nabla^2 z\\) where \\(\\alpha\\) is the thermal diffusivity. We consider the impact of a time-varying boundary condition applied as \\(f(z) = e^{Bt}z\\) where B is a constant scalar.

If the initial condition z(0) at t = 0 is modified by \\(f(z) = e^{Bt}z\\) and then allowed to evolve according to the heat equation without further intervention, will the temperature distribution z(T) at time T be the same as if \\(z(0)\\) were evolved directly by the heat equation?
Explanation: The function \\(f(z)\\) alters the initial condition which affects how the equation propagates the temperature through space and time. Modifying \\(z(0)\\) by multiplying with \\(e^{Bt}\\) changes the initial state, hence the evolved state z(T) under the heat equation will also be different, due to the modification in the distribution by the factor \\(e^{Bt}\\) initially.
